verses.text: And I looked, and behold, the Lamb was standing on Mount Zion, and with him were one hundred forty-four thousand, who had his name and his Father's name written on their foreheads.
verses.comment: The Lamb refers to Christ, standing in victory on Zion, a symbol of God's dwelling and authority. The 144,000 is a symbolic number representing completeness and God's faithful people, potentially a reference to the fullness of God's people rather than a literal count (see Rev. 7:4). The reference to God's name written on foreheads echoes the spiritual sealing of God's people.

verses.text: And I heard a sound from heaven, like the roar of many waters and like the sound of loud thunder. The sound I heard was like harpists playing their harps.
verses.comment: The majestic and harmonious sound from heaven signifies the glory and worship that surrounds God’s throne. The combination of thunder and harps suggests both power and beauty in the heavenly realm.

verses.text: And they sang a new song before the throne and before the four living creatures and the elders. No one could learn that song except the one hundred forty-four thousand, who had been redeemed from the earth.
verses.comment: The ‘new song’ marks a new act of redemption, only for those who have been especially set apart. The singing before the throne and the living beings and elders points to worship in the fullness of God’s heavenly presence.

verses.text: These are the ones who have not defiled themselves with women, for they are pure. They follow the Lamb wherever he goes. These have been redeemed from among mankind as firstfruits for God and for the Lamb.
verses.comment: ‘Not defiled…’ is symbolic of spiritual purity and dedication, not merely literal abstinence. The concept of ‘firstfruits’ recalls the consecration of a select group to God, pointing to the idea of a holy remnant set apart for divine service (see Jer. 2:3; Ex. 13:2).

verses.text: And no lie was found in their mouths; they are blameless.
verses.comment: The blamelessness of the redeemed reflects Christ’s own sinlessness (see 1 Pet. 2:21-22), emphasizing the moral transformation of those united with the Lamb.

verses.text: And I saw another angel flying overhead with the eternal gospel to proclaim to those who dwell on the earth, to every nation and tribe and language and people.
verses.comment: The ‘eternal gospel’ is the unchanging good news about God’s salvation, meant for all people. The universal scope (every nation, tribe, language, and people) points towards God’s desire to bring all humanity into fellowship with Himself.

verses.text: He said with a loud voice, ‘Fear God and give him glory, because the hour of his judgment has come; worship him who made heaven and earth, the sea and the springs of water.’
verses.comment: The call to worship God as Creator reconnects to Old Testament witness (see Ps. 96) and New Testament apostolic preaching (see Acts 17:24). This emphasizes the urgency of proper worship in light of impending judgment.

verses.text: Another angel, a second one, followed, saying, ‘Fallen, fallen is Babylon the great, who made all nations drink the wine of the passion of her immorality.’
verses.comment: Babylon represents the world system in rebellion against God, echoing both past and future judgment. Wine symbolizes the seductive and destructive nature of sin and idolatry (see Isa. 21:9).

verses.text: Then another angel, a third, followed them, saying with a loud voice, ‘If anyone worships the beast and its image and receives a mark on his forehead or on his hand,’
verses.comment: Worshiping the beast and receiving its mark represents ultimate allegiance to evil rather than God, a parallel to Old Testament warnings against idolatry.

verses.text: He will also drink the wine of God’s wrath, poured full strength into the cup of his anger, and will be tormented with fire and sulfur in the presence of the holy angels and the Lamb.
verses.comment: The imagery of wine and cup recalls God's wrath against evil (Ps. 75:8). Fire and sulfur echo the judgment upon Sodom (Gen. 19:24). The presence of the Lamb highlights Christ’s role in judgment.

verses.text: And the smoke from their torment goes up forever and ever; they have no rest day or night, those who worship the beast and its image, and whoever receives the mark of its name.
verses.comment: This verse expresses the eternal consequence of rejecting God: unending separation and suffering. The connection to Isaiah 34:10 reinforces the seriousness of this judgment.

verses.text: Here is a call for the endurance of the saints, who keep the commandments of God and the faith of Jesus.
verses.comment: Endurance and faithfulness mark true discipleship, holding fast to both God’s commandments and the testimony of Christ. The connection to obedience as well as faith highlights the full response God desires from His followers.

verses.text: And I heard a voice from heaven saying, ‘Write this: Blessed are the dead who die in the Lord from now on.’ ‘Yes,’ says the Spirit, ‘so that they may rest from their labors, for their deeds follow them.’
verses.comment: This promise of blessing for those who die in Christ emphasizes both present hope and continuity after death. The mention of works 'following' them points subtly to the value of deeds done in faith as participating in eternal reward (cf. Matt. 25:34-40).

verses.text: Then I looked, and behold, a white cloud, and sitting on the cloud was one like a son of man, having a golden crown on his head and a sharp sickle in his hand.
verses.comment: 'Son of man' directly references Daniel 7:13 and is used often for Christ. The golden crown signifies kingship and divine authority; the sickle represents judgment. Christological implication: Jesus is portrayed as both divine judge and king.

verses.text: And another angel came out of the temple, crying with a loud voice to him who sat on the cloud, ‘Put in your sickle and reap, for the hour to reap has come, because the harvest of the earth is ripe.’
verses.comment: The harvest imagery connects to Joel 3:13 and Jesus’s own parables (Matt. 13:39), showing the end-time gathering of souls for judgment.

verses.text: So he who sat on the cloud swung his sickle over the earth, and the earth was harvested.
verses.comment: This depicts the fulfillment of prophecy about the separation of the righteous from the wicked at the end of the age (see Matt. 13:41-43).

verses.text: And another angel came out of the temple in heaven, and he also had a sharp sickle.
verses.comment: 'Temple in heaven' again stresses the divine origin and authority behind the coming judgment. The sickle symbolizes the finality of God's action.

verses.text: Then another angel, who had authority over fire, came out from the altar and called with a loud voice to the one who had the sharp sickle, ‘Put in your sharp sickle and gather the clusters from the vine of the earth, for its grapes are ripe.’
verses.comment: The angel 'over fire' indicates the role of sacrifice and prayer (see Rev. 8:5, altar imagery), and the ripe grapes again allude to Joel's prophecy of judgment.

verses.text: So the angel swung his sickle over the earth and gathered the vintage of the earth, and threw it into the great winepress of the wrath of God.
verses.comment: The winepress is a powerful image of judgment. Isaiah 63:3 provides background. The 'vintage' is contrasted with Christ’s cup: wrath here, mercy elsewhere, hinting at the mystery of God’s justice and mercy.

verses.text: And the winepress was trodden outside the city, and blood came out of the winepress up to the bridles of the horses, for sixteen hundred stadia.
verses.comment: This dramatic vision highlights the completeness and severity of God’s purifying judgment. The vivid detail emphasizes the cost of sin and the absolute necessity of being united with the Lamb for salvation.
